Hi,

> 3:
> Networks containing short circuit loops. Looping is needed to compute these
> kind of networks which can make them slow. :(

By this do you mean connections that connect from the output to the
input of a single neuron? If so I think this is similar to leaky
integrator neurons. So potentially it might be better to not attempt
to evolve these types of connectivity, but to allow different types of
neuron to be used.

> 2:
> Add memory of old activations of size N to each node in the Feed Forward
> network and allow genes to go from these old computed values. This kind of
> network does not contain any loops so it is as fast to compute as the Feed
> Forward network. super nice :)

Again, keeping some memory of past activations is sort of like leaky
integrators. It's not the same but it leaky-integrators might be a
better solution depending on what you're trying to achieve. The same
goes for #4.


> One can also have two bit flags so one can choose if nodes with zero inputs, and nodes with zero outputs should be allowed to
> exist.

I think those types of nodes are always going to be redundant. If some
node or sub-network has no inputs then its output will be constant,
therefore it's output can be represented more simply with a single
connection to the bias node.

Colin
